Award.AwardTitle: Of Kayaks and Caribou Parkas: Recovering Traditional Knowledge and Exhibition Outreach
Award.AbstractNarration:
The opening of the exhibition, Yuungnaqpiallerput (The Way We Genuinely Live): Masterworks of Yup'ik Science and Survival at the Smithsonian's National Museum of Natural History in April, 2010, offers unprecedented opportunity for public education, museum collection documentation, and community engagement in science, anthropology, language revitalization, and cultural heritage. The exhibit presents remarkable 19th and early 20th century tools, containers, weapons, watercraft and clothing whose design reveals intimate understanding of the scientific principles and processes that helped Yup'ik people survive for thousands of years along Alaska's Bering Sea coast, one of the most rigorous environments on earth. The Washington venue brings hundreds of Yup'ik objects from museums around the world to the Smithsonian, where Edward W. Nelson pioneered Yup'ik studies through his 1877-81 Alaskan fieldwork and his classic publication, The Eskimos About Bering Strait (Nelson 1899).

The project utilizes workshop sessions to combine information obtained from Yup'ik elders, data from Nelson's recently discovered Alaskan diaries, and Smithsonian curatorial and conservation expertise. Participants will utilize reference collections and analytical facilities to shed light on aspects of Yup'ik science such as the selection of raw materials for strength, resilience, hardness, insulation, wind or water permeability, lightness and mechanical properties, as well as aesthetics and spiritual compatibility. In collaboration with conservators, curators and scientists, Yup'ik consultants will develop protocols for object documentation and long-term preservation and care that are both scientifically sound and culturally appropriate for the storage and educational use of museum collections. In addition to developing new research methods and standards, the project educates visitors about the importance of museum collections and Native knowledge by presenting gallery demonstrations, film programs, and children's activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This report covers a grant to the Arctic Studies Center, Smithsonian Institution, for educational outreach in support of the April 2010 National Museum of Natural History opening of Yuungnaqpiallerput (The Way We Genuinely Live): Masterworks of Yup’ik Science and Survival. NSF support was requested to enhance the educational goals of the exhibition through public programming provided by Yup’ik Native people, including dancers, artists, and oral history. Activities supported direct Yup’ik documentation of museum collections and public performances by Yupi’k dancers and artists. Curated by Ann Fienup-Riordan, the exhibit demonstrated how the consultation process can uncover and help preserve traditional knowledge held in museum collections.

Chuna McIntyre (Yup’ik): “…….You see, we Yup’ik are [here] today and let’s not forget it. We’re talking about old stuff. But then they’re connected to this moment. They’re not just some old stuff, they’re connected to us. They’re still relevant to us.”

Exhibition Precis:    As described by Fienup-Riordan: “The Yup’ik people have no word for science yet their tools were so well designed that they allowed the Yupiit to live in a land no one else would inhabit. The exhibition Yuungnaqpiallerput (The Way We Genuinely Live): Masterworks of Yup’ik Science and Survival... [is] an exploration of the scientific principles and processes that have allowed the Yup’ik people to survive in the sub-arctic tundra of the Bering Sea coast.”

Public Performances:     NSF support enabled the Arctic Studies Center to organize an opening weekend including public artifact consultations, films, dance, and gallery performances. Films included Agayuliyararput: The Living Traditions of Yup’ik Masks, The Way We Live, Eyes of the Spirit and Uksuum Cauyai: The Drums of Winter. Yup’ik elders held a blessing ceremony; Ann Fienup-Riordan led a gallery tour and gave a public lecture. Other opening activities included dance performances by the Yup’ik Upallret dance troupe wearing decorated qasperet (fancy parkas) and intricate tegumiak or dance fans. Chuna McIntyre, a nationally-known Yup’ik traditional singer, dancer, storyteller and regalia-maker, showcased his collection of parkas and lectured on the spiritual symbolism of Yup’ik parkas.

Family Activities     Using ‘edu-cart’ programs museum volunteers assisted by Yup’ik experts instructed visitors in making snow goggles and string figures and demonstrated tools Yup’ik use to manufacture clothing and implements. Edu-cart programming also provided hands-on ethnographic materials loaned from the Anchorage Museum. Visitors built a models, tested the strength of grasses, learned about tanning skins, and boat-building against their own body dimensions, and looked at stereoscopic images of the Arctic environment. Visitors experimented with making waterproof seams for garments; learned how to select suitable driftwood for building a kayak (quayaq) frame; tried on bentwood hunting hats (Ugtarcuun) that improved one’s sensory perceptions; peered through wooden snow goggles that kept one’s eyes from snow-blindness; and slipped their hands into grass insulated mittens.
